BRTHDTC.Short Description: Date (and time, if applicable and known) the participant/subject was born
BRTHDTC.Disease Specific Instructions: Record the date (and time, if applicable and known) according to the ISO 8601, the International Standard for the representation of dates and times (http://www.iso.org/iso/home.html).  The date (and time, if applicable and known) should be recorded to the level of granularity known (e.g., year, year and month, complete date plus hours and minutes, etc.).  Recording date of birth will give the most detailed information required for calculation of age and is recommended as first choice. However, in some studies recording date of birth may elicit discussions on a potential violation of privacy legislation and specifically HIPAA regulations. In these cases, the calculated age should be recorded.
Disease Specific References: ISO 8601 - http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_catalogue.htm Management and prognosis of severe traumatic brain injury: Age. J Neurotrauma. 2000
Mushkudiani NA, Engel DC, Steyerberg EW, et al. Prognostic value of demographic characteristics in traumatic brain injury: results from the IMPACT study. J Neurotrauma. Feb 2007
24(2):259-69. Pediatric-specific reference(s): Anderson V, Catroppa C, Morse S, Haritou F, Rosenfeld J (2005) Functional plasticity or vulnerability after early brain injury. Pediatrics 116:1374-1382
BRTHDTC.CDISC Notes: Date/time of birth of the subject. Control term - ISO 8601
BRTHDTC.Map to CDISC format: Per CDASH IG - Record the date of birth to the level of precision known) in this format (DD-MON-YYYY).

Age.Definition: Value for participant/subject's age, calculated as elapsed time since the birth of the participant/subject.
Age.Short Description: Value for participant/subject's age, calculated as elapsed time since the birth of the participant/subject.
Age.Disease Specific Instructions: It is recommended that age be calculated from date of birth and the study enrollment date. However, if age needs to be collected (e.g., full date of birth is not allowed to be collected) then it should be recorded in months and years.
Disease Specific References: Steyerberg EW, Mushkudiani N, Perel P, et al. Predicting outcome after traumatic brain injury: development and international validation of prognostic scores based on admission characteristics. PLoS Med. Aug 2008
5(8):e165. MRC CRASH Trial Collaborators. Predicting outcome after traumatic brain injury: practical prognostic models based on large cohort of international patients. BMJ. Feb 2008

336(7641):425-429. Pediatric-specific reference(s): Anderson V, Catroppa C, Morse S, Haritou F, Rosenfeld J (2005) Functional plasticity or vulnerability after early brain injury. Pediatrics 116:1374-1382.
Age.CDISC Notes: Age expressed in AgeU. Maybe derived from RFSTDTC and BIRTHDTC, but BRTHDTC may not be available in all cases (due to subject privacy concers)

Sex.Definition: Self-reported sex at birth of the participant/subject. The assemblage of physical properties or qualities by which male is distinguished from female; the physical difference between male and female; the distinguishing peculiarity of male or female.
Sex.Short Description: Self-reported sex at birth of the participant/subject
PV Description: 1 = Male, A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both
2 = Female, A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces ova. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, or cultural gender role distinctions, or both
3 = Unknown, Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused
4 = Intersex, A person (one of unisexual specimens) who is born with genitalia and/or secondary sexual characteristics of indeterminate sex, or which combine features of both sexes
Disease Specific References: No reference
Sex.CDISC Permissible Values: Days - C25301                                         Hours - C25529                                Months - C29846                               Weeks - C29844                                     Years - C29848
Sex.CDISC Notes: Those units of time that are routinely used to express the age of a subject

ETHNIC.Definition: Category of ethnicity the participant/subject most closely identifies with. A social group characterized by a distinctive social and cultural tradition maintained from generation to generation, a common history and origin and a sense of identification with the group; members of the group have distinctive features in their way of life, shared experiences and often a common genetic heritage; these features may be reflected in their experience of health and disease
ETHNIC.Short Description: Category of ethnicity the participant/subject most closely identifies with.
PV Description: 1 = Hispanic or Latino, A person of Mexican, Puerto Rican, Cuban, Central or South American or other Spanish culture or origin, regardless of race
2 = Not Hispanic or Latino, A person not of Cuban, Mexican, Puerto Rican, South or Central American, or other Spanish culture or origin, regardless of race. An arbitrary ethnic classification
3 = Unknown, Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused
4 = Not reported, Not provided or available
Disease Specific References: NIH Guidelines on Inclusion of Women and Minorities as Subjects in Clinical Research: The Office of Management and Budget Directive No. 15  https://grants.nih.gov/policy/inclusion/women-and-minorities/guidelines.htm

demRUCA1.CDE Name: Rural-Urban Commuting Area (RUCA) Codes - primary code
demRUCA1.Definition: The rural-urban commuting area (RUCA) codes classify U.S. locations to reflect population density, urbanization, and daily commuting. The classification contains two levels. Whole numbers (1-10) delineate metropolitan, micropolitan, small town, and rural commuting areas based on the size and direction of the primary (largest) commuting flows.
PV Description: 1 = Metropolitan area core: primary flow within an urbanized area (UA)
2 = Metropolitan area high commuting: primary flow 30% or more to a UA
3 = Metropolitan area low commuting: primary flow 10% to 30% to a UA
4 = Micropolitan area core: primary flow within an Urban Cluster of 10,000 to 49,999 (large UC)
5 = Micropolitan high commuting: primary flow 30% or more to a large UC
6 = Micropolitan low commuting: primary flow 10% to 30% to a large UC
7 = Small town core: primary flow within an Urban Cluster of 2,500 to 9,999 (small UC)
8 = Small town high commuting: primary flow 30% or more to a small UC
9 = Small town low commuting: primary flow 10% to 30% to a small UC
10 = Rural areas: primary flow to a tract outside a UA or UC
99 = Not coded: Census tract has zero population and no rural-urban identifier information
demRUCA1.Disease Specific Instructions:
Choose one.
Use tables or software to determine the code. Secondary codes are optional. The HEAL Initiative RUCA code tool is located: https://nih.box.com/s/zp5l94yte4rowyrw94pvy2d2au16qixw
Disease Specific References: USDA Economic Research Service (2022). Rural-Urban Commuting Area Codes. Economic Research Service, Department of Agriculture. https://data.nal.usda.gov/dataset/rural-urban-commuting-area-codes. Accessed 2022-05-20.
demRUCA1.CDISC Permissible Values:
Spanish-Language Document (Code C19476)
Spanish Language (Code C120587)
English Language (Code C82847)

demRUCA2.CDE Name: Rural-Urban Commuting Area (RUCA) Codes - secondary code
demRUCA2.Definition: The rural-urban commuting area (RUCA) codes classify U.S. locations to reflect population density, urbanization, and daily commuting. The classification contains two levels. The 10 primary codes can be  further subdivided based on secondary commuting flows.
PV Description: 1 = Metropolitan area core: primary flow within an urbanized area (UA) [No additional code]
1.1 = Secondary flow 30% to 50% to a larger UA
2 = Metropolitan area high commuting: primary flow 30% or more to a UA [No additional code]
2.1 = Secondary flow 30% to 50% to a larger UA
3 = Metropolitan area low commuting: primary flow 10% to 30% to a UA [No additional code]
4 = Micropolitan area core: primary flow within an Urban Cluster of 10,000 to 49,999 (large UC) [No additional code]
4.1 = Secondary flow 30% to 50% to a UA
5 = Micropolitan high commuting: primary flow 30% or more to a large UC [No additional code]
5.1 = Secondary flow 30% to 50% to a UA
6 = Micropolitan low commuting: primary flow 10% to 30% to a large UC [No additional code]
7 = Small town core: primary flow within an Urban Cluster of 2,500 to 9,999 (small UC) [No additional code]
7.1 = Secondary flow 30% to 50% to a UA
7.2 = Secondary flow 30% to 50% to a large UC
8 = Small town high commuting: primary flow 30% or more to a small UC [No additional code]
8.1 = Secondary flow 30% to 50% to a UA
8.2 = Secondary flow 30% to 50% to a large UC
9 = Small town low commuting: primary flow 10% to 30% to a small UC [No additional code]
10 = Rural areas: primary flow to a tract outside a UA or UC [No additional code]
10.1 = Secondary flow 30% to 50% to a UA
10.2 = Secondary flow 30% to 50% to a large UC
10.3 = Secondary flow 30% to 50% to a small UC
99 = Not coded: Census tract has zero population and no rural-urban identifier information
demRUCA2.Disease Specific Instructions:
Choose one.
Use tables or software to determine the code. Secondary codes are optional. The HEAL Initiative RUCA code tool is located: https://nih.box.com/s/zp5l94yte4rowyrw94pvy2d2au16qixw
Disease Specific References: USDA Economic Research Service (2022). Rural-Urban Commuting Area Codes. Economic Research Service, Department of Agriculture. https://data.nal.usda.gov/dataset/rural-urban-commuting-area-codes. Accessed 2022-05-20.

ETHNICparent.Definition: Category of ethnicity the parent/respondent most closely identifies with. A social group characterized by a distinctive social and cultural tradition maintained from generation to generation, a common history and origin and a sense of identification with the group; members of the group have distinctive features in their way of life, shared experiences and often a common genetic heritage; these features may be reflected in their experience of health and disease
PV Description: 1 = Hispanic or Latino, A person of Mexican, Puerto Rican, Cuban, Central or South American or other Spanish culture or origin, regardless of race
2 = Not Hispanic or Latino, A person not of Cuban, Mexican, Puerto Rican, South or Central American, or other Spanish culture or origin, regardless of race. An arbitrary ethnic classification
3 = Unknown, Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused
4 = Not reported, Not provided or available
Disease Specific References: NIH Guidelines on Inclusion of Women and Minorities as Subjects in Clinical Research: The Office of Management and Budget Directive No. 15  https://grants.nih.gov/policy/inclusion/women-and-minorities/guidelines.htm
ETHNICparent.CDISC Data Type: Hispanic or Latino -- C17459,                                     Not Hispanic or Latino -- C4122,                                      Unkown, Not reported --C17998
ETHNICparent.Additional Information: A social group characterized by a distinctive social and cultural tradition maintained from generation to generation, a common history and origin and a sense of identification with the group; members of the group have distinctive features in their way of life, shared experiences and often a common genetic heritage; these features may be reflected in their experience of health and disease.

AI_AN_p.Definition: Race: Parent/respondent self declared racial origination, independent of ethnic origination, using OMB approved categories. This response indicates self-declared race is American Indian or Alaska Native, A person having origins in any of the original peoples of North and South America (including Central America), and who maintains tribal affiliation or community attachment
AI_AN_p.Short Description: Parent/respondent race - American Indian or Alaska Native
AI_AN_p.Disease Specific Instructions: The participant can select one or more races
Disease Specific References: NIH Guidelines on Inclusion of Women and Minorities as Subjects in Clinical Research: The Office of Management and Budget Directive No. 15  https://grants.nih.gov/policy/inclusion/women-and-minorities/guidelines.htm
AI_AN_p.Additional Information: Terminology codelist used to identify the race of an individual within the Clinical Data Interchange Standards Consortium Study Data Tabulation Model.

GAD2FeelNervScale.CDE Name: Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD-2) - feeling nervous scale
GAD2FeelNervScale.Definition: Scale describing how often participant/subject has been bothered by feeling nervous, anxious or on edge, as a part of Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD-2)
GAD2FeelNervScale.Short Description: Scale describing how often participant/subject has been bothered by feeling nervous, anxious or on edge, as a part of Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD-2)
GAD2FeelNervScale.Additional Notes (Question Text): Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge
Disease Specific References: Kroenke K, Spitzer RL, Williams JB, Monahan PO, Löwe B. Anxiety disorders in primary care: Prevalence, impairment, comorbidity, and detection. Ann Intern Med. 2007
GAD2FeelNervScale.Notes: The GAD-2 is based on the GAD-7. This question, "Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by the following problems? 1. Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge", corresponds to the first question on the Gad-7.

GAD2NotStopWryScale.CDE Name: Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD-2) - not stop worry scale
GAD2NotStopWryScale.Definition: Scale describing how often participant/subject has not been able to stop or control worrying, as a part of Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD-2).
GAD2NotStopWryScale.Short Description: Scale describing how often participant/subject has not been able to stop or control worrying, as a part of Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD-2).
GAD2NotStopWryScale.Additional Notes (Question Text): Not being able to stop or control worrying
Disease Specific References: Kroenke K, Spitzer RL, Williams JB, Monahan PO, Löwe B. Anxiety disorders in primary care: Prevalence, impairment, comorbidity, and detection. Ann Intern Med. 2007
GAD2NotStopWryScale.Notes: The GAD-2 is based on the GAD-7. The question, "Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by the following problems? 2. Not being able to stop or control worrying", corresponds to the second question on the Gad-7.

GAD2TotalScore.Disease Specific Instructions: Sum the responses for both questions (total score).
Disease Specific References: Kroenke K, Spitzer RL, Williams JB, Monahan PO, Löwe B. Anxiety disorders in primary care: Prevalence, impairment, comorbidity, and detection. Ann Intern Med. 2007
GAD2TotalScore.Notes: A score of 3 points is the preferred cut-off for identifying possible cases and in which further diagnostic evaluation for generalized anxiety disorder is warranted.

PCSCWorryPainEndScale.CDE Name: Pain Catastrophizing Scale - Child (PCS-C) Worry Whether Pain will End Scale
PCSCWorryPainEndScale.Definition: Scale describing how much the participant/subject worries all the time about whether pain will end; part of the Pain Catastrophizing Scale - Child (PCS-C)
PCSCWorryPainEndScale.Short Description: Scale describing how much the participant/subject worries about whether pain will end; part of the PCS-C
PCSCWorryPainEndScale.Additional Notes (Question Text): When I have pain I worry all the time whether the pain will end
PCSCWorryPainEndScale.Disease Specific Instructions: We are interested in the thoughts and feelings you have when you are in pain. Below are sentences of different thoughts and feelings.  Please check the box for the word or phrase under each sentence that best reflects how strongly you have each thought when you are in pain.
Disease Specific References: (1)Crombez G, Bijttebier P, et al. The child version of the pain catastrophizing scale (PCS-C): a preliminary validation. Pain 2003, 104 (3), pp. 639-646

(2) Pielech M, Ryan M, et al. Pain catastrophizing in children with chronic pain and their parents: Proposed clinical reference points and reexamination of the PCS measure. Pain 2014, 155(11), 2360-2367

PCSCCantGoOnScale.CDE Name: Pain Catastrophizing Scale - Child (PCS-C) Feel Cannot Go On Scale
PCSCCantGoOnScale.Definition: Scale describing how much the participant/subject feels they cannot go on when they have pain; part of the Pain Catastrophizing Scale - Child (PCS-C)
PCSCCantGoOnScale.Short Description: Scale describing how much the participant/subject feels they can't go on when they have pain, part of the PCS-C
PCSCCantGoOnScale.Additional Notes (Question Text): When I have pain I feel I can’t go on
Disease Specific References: (1)Crombez G, Bijttebier P, et al. The child version of the pain catastrophizing scale (PCS-C): a preliminary validation. Pain 2003, 104 (3), pp. 639-646

(2) Pielech M, Ryan M, et al. Pain catastrophizing in children with chronic pain and their parents: Proposed clinical reference points and reexamination of the PCS measure. Pain 2014, 155(11), 2360-2367

PCSCNeverGetBetterScale.CDE Name: Pain Catastrophizing Scale - Child (PCS-C) Never Get Better Scale
PCSCNeverGetBetterScale.Definition: Scale describing how much the participant/subject feels pain is terrible and will never get better; part of the Pain Catastrophizing Scale - Child (PCS-C)
PCSCNeverGetBetterScale.Short Description: Scale describing how much the participant/subject feels pain  will never get better, part of the PCS-C
PCSCNeverGetBetterScale.Additional Notes (Question Text): When I have pain it’s terrible and I think it’s never going to get better
Disease Specific References: (1)Crombez G, Bijttebier P, et al. The child version of the pain catastrophizing scale (PCS-C): a preliminary validation. Pain 2003, 104 (3), pp. 639-646

(2) Pielech M, Ryan M, et al. Pain catastrophizing in children with chronic pain and their parents: Proposed clinical reference points and reexamination of the PCS measure. Pain 2014, 155(11), 2360-2367

PCSCOverwhelmScale.CDE Name: Pain Catastrophizing Scale - Child (PCS-C) Pain Overwhelms Scale
PCSCOverwhelmScale.Definition: Scale describing how much the participant/subject feels that pain is awful and takes over (overwhelms) them; part of the Pain Catastrophizing Scale - Child (PCS-C)
PCSCOverwhelmScale.Short Description: Scale describing how much the participant/subject feels that pain is overwhelming; part of the PCS-C
PCSCOverwhelmScale.Additional Notes (Question Text): When I have pain it’s awful and I feel it takes over me
Disease Specific References: (1)Crombez G, Bijttebier P, et al. The child version of the pain catastrophizing scale (PCS-C): a preliminary validation. Pain 2003, 104 (3), pp. 639-646

(2) Pielech M, Ryan M, et al. Pain catastrophizing in children with chronic pain and their parents: Proposed clinical reference points and reexamination of the PCS measure. Pain 2014, 155(11), 2360-2367

PCSCCantStandPainScale.CDE Name: Pain Catastrophizing Scale - Child (PCS-C) Can not Stand Pain Scale
PCSCCantStandPainScale.Definition: Scale describing how much the participant/subject feels that they can no longer stand the pain; part of the Pain Catastrophizing Scale - Child (PCS-C)
PCSCCantStandPainScale.Short Description: Scale describing how much the participant/subject feels they cannot stand the pain; part of the PCS-C
PCSCCantStandPainScale.Additional Notes (Question Text): When I have pain I feel I can’t stand it anymore
Disease Specific References: (1)Crombez G, Bijttebier P, et al. The child version of the pain catastrophizing scale (PCS-C): a preliminary validation. Pain 2003, 104 (3), pp. 639-646

(2) Pielech M, Ryan M, et al. Pain catastrophizing in children with chronic pain and their parents: Proposed clinical reference points and reexamination of the PCS measure. Pain 2014, 155(11), 2360-2367

PCSCPainWorsenScale.CDE Name: Pain Catastrophizing Scale - Child (PCS-C) Fear Pain will Worsen Scale
PCSCPainWorsenScale.Definition: Scale describing how much the participant/subject fears that pain will get worse; part of the Pain Catastrophizing Scale - Child (PCS-C)

Choose one

PEGAvgPainPastWeekScl.CDE Name: PEG - average pain past week scale
PEGAvgPainPastWeekScl.Definition: Scale indicating the rating of past week average pain experienced by the subject, as part of the PEG form.
PEGAvgPainPastWeekScl.Short Description: Scale indicating the rating of the past week average pain, as part of the PEG form.
PEGAvgPainPastWeekScl.Additional Notes (Question Text): What number best describes your pain on average in the past week?
PV Description: 10 = Pain as bad as you can imagine
PEGAvgPainPastWeekScl.Disease Specific Instructions: Select the one number that describes your average pain in the past week. Use the scale of 0 = No pain and 10 = Pain as bad as you can imagine
Disease Specific References: Krebs EE, Lorenz KA, Bair MJ, Damush TM, Wu J, Sutherland JM, Asch SM, Kroenke K. Development and initial validation of the PEG, a three-item scale assessing pain intensity and interference. J Gen Intern Med. 2009

PEGPainPastWkEnjoyLifeScl.Additional Notes (Question Text): What number best describes how, during the past week, pain has interfered with your enjoyment of life?
PEGPainPastWkEnjoyLifeScl.Disease Specific Instructions: Select the one number that describes your pain interfering with your enjoyment of life. Use the scale of 0 = Does not interfere and 10 = Completely interferes
Disease Specific References: Krebs EE, Lorenz KA, Bair MJ, Damush TM, Wu J, Sutherland JM, Asch SM, Kroenke K. Development and initial validation of the PEG, a three-item scale assessing pain intensity and interference. J Gen Intern Med. 2009
PEGPainPastWkEnjoyLifeScl.Notes: This question, "What number best describes how, during the past week, pain has interfered with your enjoyment of life?" corresponds to question 7, "Enjoyment of life" found on the on the Brief Pain Inventory-7 (BPI-7)

PEGPainPastWkGenrlActScl.CDE Name: PEG - pain past week general activity scale
PEGPainPastWkGenrlActScl.Definition: Scale indicating the rating of past week pain general activity experienced by the subject, as part of the PEG form.
PEGPainPastWkGenrlActScl.Short Description: Scale indicating the rating of past week pain general activity experienced by the subject, as part of the PEG form.
PEGPainPastWkGenrlActScl.Additional Notes (Question Text): What number best describes how, during the past week, pain has interfered with your general activity?
PEGPainPastWkGenrlActScl.Disease Specific Instructions: Select the one number that describes your pain interfering with your general activity. Use the scale of 0 = Does not interfere and 10 = Completely interferes
Disease Specific References: Krebs EE, Lorenz KA, Bair MJ, Damush TM, Wu J, Sutherland JM, Asch SM, Kroenke K. Development and initial validation of the PEG, a three-item scale assessing pain intensity and interference. J Gen Intern Med. 2009
PEGPainPastWkGenrlActScl.Notes: This question, "What number best describes how, during the past week, pain has interfered with your general activity??" corresponds to question 1, "General Activity" found on the on the Brief Pain Inventory-7 (BPI-7)

PEGOverallScore.Definition: Computed overall score for the PEG, calculated as the arithmetic mean (average; sum of scores divided by 3).
PEGOverallScore.Short Description: Computed overall score for the PEG, calculated as the arithmetic mean (average; sum of scores divided by 3).
PEGOverallScore.Disease Specific Instructions: calculated as the arithmetic mean (average; sum of scores divided by 3).
Disease Specific References: Krebs EE, Lorenz KA, Bair MJ, Damush TM, Wu J, Sutherland JM, Asch SM, Kroenke K. Development and initial validation of the PEG, a three-item scale assessing pain intensity and interference. J Gen Intern Med. 2009

PGICSymptomChangeStatVal.CDE Name: Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC) Symptom change status value
PGICSymptomChangeStatVal.Definition: Status describing the change in the subject's symptoms have since the beginning of treatment as a part of the Patient Global Impression of Change
PGICSymptomChangeStatVal.Short Description: Status describing the change in the subject's symptoms have since the beginning of treatment as a part of the Patient Global Impression of Change
PGICSymptomChangeStatVal.Additional Notes (Question Text): Since the start of the study (treatment), my overall pain is ….
PGICSymptomChangeStatVal.Disease Specific Instructions: Mark the statement that best describes the change (if any) in your symptoms.
Disease Specific References: Farrar JT, Young JP Jr, LaMoreaux L, Werth JL, Poole RM. Clinical importance of changes in chronic pain intensity measured on an 11-point numerical pain rating scale. Pain. 2001

94(2):149-158.
Perrot S, Lantéri-Minet M. Patients' Global Impression of Change in the management of peripheral neuropathic pain: Clinical relevance and correlations in daily practice. Eur J Pain. 2019

PGISSeverityScale.CDE Name: Patient Global Impression of Severity (PGIS) pain severity scale
PGISSeverityScale.Definition: Single item scale describing the participant/subject perception about overall pain severity
PGISSeverityScale.Short Description: Scale describing the participant/subject perception about overall pain severity
PGISSeverityScale.Additional Notes (Question Text): Please choose the response that best describes the severity of your pain over the past week.
Disease Specific References: Yalcin I, Bump R. Validation of two global impression questionnaires for incontinence. Am J Obstet Gynecol 2003
US Food and Drug Administration (FDA). Patient-Focused Drug 2 Development Public Workshop. October 15-16 2018.
See also https://www.fda.gov/media/116281/download
PGISSeverityScale.Notes: Related to Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (Overall JE, Gorham DR (1962). The brief psychiatric rating scale. Psychological Reports 1962 vol. 10, pp799-812) and Clinical Global Impression (CGI) scale (Busner J & Targum SD. (2007). The Clinical Global Impressions Scale. Psychiatry, 4(7):28-37.) See also https://www.physio-pedia.com/Patient_Global_Impression_of_Severity_(PGI-S). Note that scale starts at 1 rather than 0                                                                      // PIs should use either the PGIS or the PGIC

PHQLitIntrstScore.CDE Name: Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ) - Little interest score
PHQLitIntrstScore.Definition: Score of how much the subject has been bothered by having little interest or pleasure in doing things in the past two weeks, as part of the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ).
PHQLitIntrstScore.Short Description: Score of how much the subject has been bothered by having little interest or pleasure in doing things in the past two weeks, as part of the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ).
PHQLitIntrstScore.Additional Notes (Question Text): Over the last 2 weeks how often have you been bothered by having little interest or pleasure in doing things?
Disease Specific References: Kroenke K, Spitzer RL, Williams JB. The Patient Health Questionnaire-2: validity of a two-item depression screener. Med Care. 2003

PHQDeprssnScore.Definition: Score of how much the subject has been feeling down and depressed in the past two weeks, as part of the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ).
PHQDeprssnScore.Short Description: Score of how much the subject has been feeling down and depressed in the past two weeks, as part of the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ).
PHQDeprssnScore.Additional Notes (Question Text): Over the last 2 weeks how often have you been bothered by feeling down depressed or hopeless?
Disease Specific References: Kroenke K, Spitzer RL, Williams JB. The Patient Health Questionnaire-2: validity of a two-item depression screener. Med Care. 2003

PHQ2TotalScore.Disease Specific Instructions: Sum the responses for both questions (total score).
Disease Specific References: Kroenke K, Spitzer RL, Williams JB. The Patient Health Questionnaire-2: validity of a two-item depression screener. Med Care. 2003
PHQ2TotalScore.Notes: A score of 3 points is the preferred cut-off for identifying possible cases of depression.

SleepNightHourMinDur.Definition: Duration in hours and minutes of sleep per night by the participant/subject.
SleepNightHourMinDur.Short Description: Duration in hours and minutes of sleep per night by the participant/subject.
SleepNightHourMinDur.Additional Notes (Question Text): During the past month, how many hours and minutes of actual sleep did you get at night? (This may be different than the number of hours and minutes you spent in bed).
SleepNightHourMinDur.Disease Specific Instructions: Enter the number of hours and minutes slept per night. It may be desirable to collect hours (sleepNightHourDur) and minutes (sleepNightMinDur) separately and then combine for analysis. SleepNightHourMinDur = sleepNightHourDur + (sleepNightMinDur/60)
Disease Specific References: Buysse, DJ, Reynolds CF, Monk TH, Berman SR, Kupfer DJ: The Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI): A new instrument for psychiatric research and practice. Psychiatry Research 28:193-213, 1989

ASWSStayUpScale.CDE Name: Adolescent Sleep Wake Scale (ASWS) - want to stay up scale
ASWSStayUpScale.Definition: Scale describing typical weekday sleep pattern for how frequently (what percent of the time time) participant/subject wants to stay up when it is time to go to bed, as a part of Adolescent Sleep Wake Scale (ASWS)
ASWSStayUpScale.Short Description: Scale describing how frequently participant/subject wants to stay up at bedtime, as a part of Adolescent Sleep Wake Scale (ASWS)
ASWSStayUpScale.Additional Notes (Question Text): When it's time to go to bed I want to stay up and do other things (for example: watch TV, play video games, or talk on the phone).
ASWSStayUpScale.Disease Specific Instructions: Using the choices below, select how often the following things have happened during the past month. Questions 1 - 3 are only about you Going to Bed at bedtime.
Disease Specific References: Lebourgeois, M. K., Giannotti, F., Cortesi, F., Wolfson, A. R. & Harsh, J. (2005) The relationship between reported sleep quality and sleep hygiene in Italian and American adolescents. Pediatrics, 115, 257– 265. Essner, B., Noel, M., Myrvik, M. & Palermo, T. (2015) Examination of the factor structure of the Adolescent Sleep–Wake Scale (ASWS). Behavioral Sleep Medicine, 13, 296– 307. Sufrinko, A. M., Valrie, C. R., Lanzo, L., Bond, K. E., Trout, K. L., Ladd, R. E. & Everhart, D. E. (2015) Empirical validation of a short version of the Adolescent Sleep–Wake Scale using a sample of ethnically diverse adolescents from an economically disadvantage community. Sleep Medicine, 16, 1204– 1206.
ASWSStayUpScale.Notes: ASWS. Going to bed scale. Reverse code

ASWSReadyGoBedScale.Additional Notes (Question Text): In general I am ready to go to bed at bedtime
Disease Specific References: Lebourgeois, M. K., Giannotti, F., Cortesi, F., Wolfson, A. R. & Harsh, J. ASWSGoingToBedScore.CDE Name: Adolescent Sleep Wake Scale (ASWS) Going to Bed subscale score
ASWSGoingToBedScore.Definition: Calculated subscale score for Going To Bed; as part of the Adolescent Sleep Wake Scale (ASWS)
ASWSGoingToBedScore.Disease Specific Instructions: Reverse score response to questions 1 and 3 (as 1r and 3r). Compute the mean of 1r, 2, 3r

ASWSFallingAsleepScore.Short Description: Falling Asleep and Staying Asleep ASWS (calculated)
ASWSFallingAsleepScore.Additional Notes (Question Text): Falling Asleep and Staying Asleep ASWS
ASWSFallingAsleepScore.Disease Specific Instructions: Reverse score response to questions 4, 5, 6, 7, and 8 (as 4r, 5r, 6r, 7r, 8r). Compute the mean of 4r, 5r, 6r, 7r, 8r
Disease Specific References: Essner B, Noel M, Myrvik M, Palermo T. Examination of the Factor Structure of the Adolescent Sleep-Wake Scale (ASWS). Behav Sleep Med. 2015

ASWSTotalAvgScore.CDE Name: Adolescent Sleep Wake Scale (ASWS) Total Measure score

ASWSTotalAvgScore.Disease Specific Instructions: Reverse score responses to questions 1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8  (as 1r, 3r, 4r, 5r, 6r, 7r, 8r). Compute the mean of 1r, 2, 3r, 4r, 5r, 6r, 7r, 8r, 9, 10

TAPSTobaccoProductScl.CDE Name: Tobacco Alcohol Prescription medications and other Substance (TAPS) -  Tobacco product use scale
TAPSTobaccoProductScl.Definition: Status indicating the participant's tobacco use in the past 12 months as a part of the Tobacco Alcohol and Prescription medications and other Substance (TAPS)
TAPSTobaccoProductScl.Short Description: Status indicating the participant's tobacco use in the past 12 months as a part of the Tobacco Alcohol and Prescription medications and other Substance (TAPS)
TAPSTobaccoProductScl.Additional Notes (Question Text): In the PAST 12 MONTHS, how often have you used any tobacco product (for example, cigarettes, e-cigarettes, cigars, pipes, or smokeless tobacco)?
TAPSTobaccoProductScl.Disease Specific Instructions: Mark the number next to the statement that best describes how often you have used any tobacco products in the past 12 months
Disease Specific References: McNeely J, Wu LT, Subramaniam G, Sharma G, Cathers LA, Svikis D, Sleiter L, Russell L, Nordeck C, Sharma A, O'Grady KE, Bouk LB, Cushing C, King J, Wahle A, Schwartz RP. Performance of the Tobacco, Alcohol, Prescription Medication, and Other Substance Use (TAPS) Tool for Substance Use Screening in Primary Care Patients. Ann Intern Med. 2016

TAPSAlcoholUseMaleScl.CDE Name: Tobacco Alcohol Prescription medications and other Substance (TAPS) - Alcohol use male scale
TAPSAlcoholUseMaleScl.Definition: Status indicating the male participant's alcohol use in the past 12 months as a part of the Tobacco Alcohol and Prescription medications and other Substance (TAPS)
TAPSAlcoholUseMaleScl.Short Description: Status indicating the male participant's alcohol use in the past 12 months as a part of the Tobacco Alcohol and Prescription medications and other Substance (TAPS)
TAPSAlcoholUseMaleScl.Additional Notes (Question Text): In the PAST 12 MONTHS, how often have you had 5 or more drinks containing alcohol in one day? One standard drink is about 1 small glass of wine (5 oz), 1 beer (12 oz), or 1 single shot of liquor. (Answer based on response to sex at birth, not gender identity. If sex at birth is marked “intersex” or “unknown” use the version of the question using “4 or more drinks containing alcohol in one day.” )
TAPSAlcoholUseMaleScl.Disease Specific Instructions:
This question should only be answered by males.
Mark the number next to the statement that best describes your alcohol use in the past 12 months.
Disease Specific References: McNeely J, Wu LT, Subramaniam G, Sharma G, Cathers LA, Svikis D, Sleiter L, Russell L, Nordeck C, Sharma A, O'Grady KE, Bouk LB, Cushing C, King J, Wahle A, Schwartz RP. Performance of the Tobacco, Alcohol, Prescription Medication, and Other Substance Use (TAPS) Tool for Substance Use Screening in Primary Care Patients. Ann Intern Med. 2016

TAPSAlcoholUseFemaleScl.CDE Name: Tobacco Alcohol Prescription medications and other Substance (TAPS) - Alcohol use female scale
TAPSAlcoholUseFemaleScl.Definition: Status indicating the female participant's alcohol use in the past 12 months as a part of the Tobacco Alcohol and Prescription medications and other Substance (TAPS)

TAPSAlcoholUseFemaleScl.Additional Notes (Question Text): In the PAST 12 MONTHS, how often have you had 4 or more drinks containing alcohol in one day? One standard drink is about 1 small glass of wine (5 oz), 1 beer (12 oz), or 1 single shot of liquor. (Answer based on response to sex at birth, not gender identity. If sex at birth is marked “intersex” or “unknown” use the version of the question using “4 or more drinks containing alcohol in one day.” )
TAPSAlcoholUseFemaleScl.Disease Specific Instructions:
This question should only be answered by females.
Mark the number next to the statement that best describes your alcohol use in the past 12 months.
Disease Specific References: McNeely J, Wu LT, Subramaniam G, Sharma G, Cathers LA, Svikis D, Sleiter L, Russell L, Nordeck C, Sharma A, O'Grady KE, Bouk LB, Cushing C, King J, Wahle A, Schwartz RP. Performance of the Tobacco, Alcohol, Prescription Medication, and Other Substance Use (TAPS) Tool for Substance Use Screening in Primary Care Patients. Ann Intern Med. 2016

TAPSDrugUseScl.CDE Name: Tobacco Alcohol Prescription medications and other Substance (TAPS) - Drug use scale
TAPSDrugUseScl.Definition: Status indicating the participant's drug use in the past 12 months as a part of the Tobacco Alcohol and Prescription medications and other Substance (TAPS)
TAPSDrugUseScl.Short Description: Status indicating the participant's drug use in the past 12 months as a part of the Tobacco Alcohol and Prescription medications and other Substance (TAPS)
TAPSDrugUseScl.Additional Notes (Question Text): In the PAST 12 MONTHS, how often have you used any drugs including marijuana, cocaine or crack,heroin, methamphetamine (crystal meth), hallucinogens, ecstasy/MDMA?
TAPSDrugUseScl.Disease Specific Instructions: Mark the number next to the statement that best describes your drug use in the past 12 months.
Disease Specific References: McNeely J, Wu LT, Subramaniam G, Sharma G, Cathers LA, Svikis D, Sleiter L, Russell L, Nordeck C, Sharma A, O'Grady KE, Bouk LB, Cushing C, King J, Wahle A, Schwartz RP. TAPSPrescriptionMedUseScl.CDE Name: Tobacco Alcohol Prescription medications and other Substance (TAPS) - Prescription medication use scale
TAPSPrescriptionMedUseScl.Definition: Status indicating the participant's perscription medication use in the past 12 months as a part of the Tobacco Alcohol and Prescription medications and other Substance (TAPS)
TAPSPrescriptionMedUseScl.Short Description: Status indicating the participant's perscription medication use in the past 12 months as a part of the Tobacco Alcohol and Prescription medications and other Substance (TAPS)
TAPSPrescriptionMedUseScl.Additional Notes (Question Text): In the PAST 12 MONTHS, how often have you used any prescription medications just for the feeling, more than prescribed or that were not prescribed for you? Prescription medications that may be used this way include: Opiate pain relievers (for example, OxyContin, Vicodin, Percocet, Methadone) Medications for anxiety or sleeping (for example, Xanax, Ativan, Klonopin) Medications for ADHD (for example, Adderall or Ritalin)
TAPSPrescriptionMedUseScl.Disease Specific Instructions: Mark the number next to the statement that best describes your prescription medication use in the past 12 months.
Disease Specific References: McNeely J, Wu LT, Subramaniam G, Sharma G, Cathers LA, Svikis D, Sleiter L, Russell L, Nordeck C, Sharma A, O'Grady KE, Bouk LB, Cushing C, King J, Wahle A, Schwartz RP. Performance of the Tobacco, Alcohol, Prescription Medication, and Other Substance Use (TAPS) Tool for Substance Use Screening in Primary Care Patients. Ann Intern Med. 2016

TAPSOverallYN.CDE Name: Tobacco Alcohol Prescription medications and other Substance (TAPS) - Overall TAPS possible substance use indicator
TAPSOverallYN.Definition: Indicator evaluating the overall set of responses to the Tobacco Alcohol Prescription medications and other Substance (TAPS) part 1
TAPSOverallYN.Disease Specific Instructions: Derived score. If any item in the TAPS part 1 has a response other than "Never" then score this item as positive (1)
Disease Specific References: McNeely J, Wu LT, Subramaniam G, Sharma G, Cathers LA, Svikis D, Sleiter L, Russell L, Nordeck C, Sharma A, O'Grady KE, Bouk LB, Cushing C, King J, Wahle A, Schwartz RP. Performance of the Tobacco, Alcohol, Prescription Medication, and Other Substance Use (TAPS) Tool for Substance Use Screening in Primary Care Patients. Ann Intern Med. 2016
TAPSOverallYN.Notes: No formal computation has been validated, but this response could be computed as positive = a mean score less than 4.0
